slides.title: Key Figures

jennifer_doudna.name: Jennifer Doudna, PhD
background: UC Berkeley biochemist; co-discovered programmable CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing (2012)
Pioneered governance and ethical discourse for genome editing
2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry (with Emmanuelle Charpentier)
jennifer_doudna.quote: This technology gives us a way to rewrite the code of life. With that power comes profound responsibility.

emmanuelle_charpentier.name: Emmanuelle Charpentier, PhD
background: Microbiologist who identified tracrRNA and co-invented the CRISPR-Cas9 editing system
Founding and scientific leadership at the Max Planck Unit for the Science of Pathogens
emmanuelle_charpentier.quote: CRISPR is a simple concept with transformative implications when directed with precision and care.

slides.title: How CRISPR Works

diagram_layers: Target selection: Cas9 scans DNA for a PAM (e.g., NGG) and the 20-nt guide RNA (gRNA) base-pairs with the protospacer.
Cutting: Cas9’s HNH and RuvC domains cleave opposite strands to create a double-strand break (DSB).
Repair path A—NHEJ: Error-prone repair introduces small indels, often yielding gene knockout.
Repair path B—HDR: With a donor template, precise edits/insertions are made at the break site.
editor_variants: Base editors (ABE/CBE): nCas9 or dCas9 fused to a deaminase; single-base conversions (A↔G, C↔T) without DSB.
Prime editor: nCas9 fused to reverse transcriptase with a pegRNA; installs small insertions/deletions/substitutions with minimal cutting.

glossary.gRNA: Guide RNA that directs the nuclease to a matching DNA sequence
glossary.PAM: Protospacer Adjacent Motif required for nuclease binding (e.g., NGG for SpCas9)
glossary.RNP: Ribonucleoprotein complex of Cas protein and gRNA, used for transient editing

slides.title: Breakthroughs Timeline

timeline.proof_point: In vitro demonstration of RNA-guided DNA cleavage (Jinek et al., Science)
CRISPR-Cas9 enables targeted gene disruption and HDR in human cells
Cytosine and adenine base editors expand precise, DSB-free editing
Versatile small insertions/deletions/substitutions without donor DNA
Recognition of Doudna and Charpentier for CRISPR-Cas9

timeline.milestone: First in vivo CRISPR infusion shows strong target knockdown
timeline.proof_point: ATTR program demonstrates dose-dependent TTR reduction after a single IV dose
In vivo base editing of PCSK9 shows sustained LDL-C lowering

timeline.milestone: First regulatory approvals of a CRISPR therapy
timeline.proof_point: Exagamglogene autotemcel (exa-cel/CASGEVY) approved for severe SCD; broader indications and regions follow

slides.title: Delivery Modalities: Getting Editors to Cells

AAV.works_best_for: In vivo editing in tissues with suitable serotypes (e.g., eye, muscle, CNS subtypes)
constraints: Capsid size limits (~4.7 kb) constrain editor payloads
Potential for vector integration and liver toxicity at high doses
notables: Dual-AAV or compact nucleases (SaCas9) mitigate payload limits

LNP.works_best_for: In vivo delivery to liver; expanding to extrahepatic targets via ligand/capsid engineering
pros: Transient expression reduces prolonged exposure risk
Amenable to repeat dosing in some contexts
constraints: Endosomal escape efficiency is a key bottleneck
notables: NTLA-2001 (Cas9 mRNA + gRNA LNP) for ATTR
VERVE-101 (ABE mRNA + gRNA LNP) for PCSK9

Electroporation (ex vivo).works_best_for: Autologous/allogeneic cell therapies (HSPCs, T cells, NK cells)
pros: High editing rates and multiplex capability
constraints: Logistics of cell collection and release testing

pros: Potential for targeted delivery with ligands/antibodies

slides.title: Clinical Risks, Ethics & Regulation

mitigations: High-fidelity nucleases (e.g., eSpCas9, HiFi Cas9, Cas12a)
Orthogonal off-target mapping (GUIDE-seq, CIRCLE-seq, CHANGE-seq, DISCOVER-Seq)
Dose minimization and transient delivery (RNP, mRNA/LNP)

safety_risks_and_mitigations.risk: On-target complexity (large deletions, rearrangements, p53 activation)
mitigations: Long-read sequencing and junction PCR in release testing
Functional assays for tumor suppressor pathways
Integration site analysis; biodistribution/tox study rigor
Patient selection and LFT monitoring, steroid protocols

safety_risks_and_mitigations.risk: Immunity to Cas proteins or vectors
mitigations: Pre-screen for neutralizing antibodies where relevant
Prophylaxis and monitoring for infusion reactions
In-process controls, potency assays, deep sequencing QC

monitoring_toolkit: Amplicon NGS and WGS (short + long read)
Clinical labs: hematology, chemistry, immunogenicity panels
Long-term follow-up registries (up to 15 years for gene-modifying therapies)
ethics_topics: Somatic vs. germline boundary—therapeutic use only in humans
Informed consent and long-term data stewardship
Avoiding enhancement uses and guarding against misuse

regulatory_overview.US_FDA: CBER draft guidance (2022): Human Gene Therapy Products Incorporating Human Genome Editing; expectations for off-target assessment, CMC, and long-term follow-up
regulatory_overview.EU_EMA: ATMP framework; gene editing under gene therapy guidelines; CHMP methodological guidance for biodistribution, shedding, and long-term safety
regulatory_overview.UK_MHRA: ILAP/Innovation pathways facilitate accelerated access with robust risk management
regulatory_overview.WHO: 2021 recommendations for governance and oversight of human genome editing

slides.title: Case Studies & What’s Next

case_studies.modality: Ex vivo CRISPR/Cas9 RNP; autologous HSPC edit (BCL11A enhancer)
case_studies.indication: Severe sickle cell disease; transfusion‑dependent β‑thalassemia
key_results: High rates of elimination of severe vaso‑occlusive crises (SCD)
Durable HbF induction; transfusion independence in many TDT patients

case_studies.modality: In vivo CRISPR/Cas9 via LNP (mRNA + gRNA)
key_results: Single IV dose achieves dose‑dependent TTR reductions (often >80–90%)
case_studies.notes: Demonstrates systemic in vivo editing feasibility in humans

case_studies.modality: In vivo adenine base editor (ABE) via LNP
key_results: Sustained LDL‑C lowering in early clinical data
case_studies.notes: First clinical base editing program; long‑term durability under observation

whats_next: Prime editing enters/approaches clinical testing for precise corrections
Targeted LNPs and next‑gen capsids broaden beyond liver (lung, muscle, CNS)
In vivo gene insertion and safe‑harbor strategies for durable replacement
Multiplex editing for off‑the‑shelf cell therapies with logic gating
CRISPRi/a and epigenome editing for reversible gene control
Manufacturing scale‑out, closed systems, and outcomes‑based pricing to expand access
